content.text: Once upon a time, in a small village nestled between rolling green hills and a sparkling river, there lived a kind and clever girl named Lila.
Lila was known far and wide for her quick wit and her kind heart.
She lived with her grandmother in a cozy little cottage at the edge of the village, where the wildflowers grew tall and the bees hummed sweetly in the summer sun.
One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon and painted the sky with hues of pink and gold, Lila’s grandmother sat by the fire, mending a torn shawl.
Lila, who had just returned from gathering firewood, plopped down beside her and asked, *"Grandmother, why do the villagers always come to you for advice?
You always know just what to say!"*  Grandmother chuckled, her eyes twinkling like the stars beginning to peek out from the twilight.
*"Ah, my dear,"* she said, *"wisdom is like a river—it flows from listening, from watching, and from thinking before speaking.
And sometimes, the answers come not from what we know, but from what we ask."*  Lila tilted her head, her brow furrowing in thought.
*"But how do you know the right questions to ask?"*  Grandmother smiled and set down her needle.
*"That, my clever girl, is a lesson for another day. For now, it’s time for bed.
Tomorrow, we’ll have much to do—there’s a great feast in the village, and the mayor has asked for my help with a problem."*  Lila’s eyes widened with excitement.
*"A problem? What kind of problem?"*  *"Oh, it’s nothing to worry about,"* Grandmother said, tucking Lila into bed.
*"Now close your eyes and dream of honey cakes and dancing fireflies."*  But Lila couldn’t sleep.
Her mind buzzed with curiosity. What could the mayor’s problem be? And why did he need Grandmother’s help?
She tossed and turned until the moon climbed high in the sky, and at last, she drifted into a restless sleep.
---  The next morning, Lila woke to the sound of clucking hens and the smell of fresh bread baking in the oven.
She dressed quickly and hurried to the village square, where long tables were being set up for the feast.
The mayor, a round man with a booming laugh, stood in the center of the square, looking rather flustered.
*"Ah, there you are!"* he called when he spotted Lila’s grandmother. *"Good people of the village, gather ‘round!
We have a most peculiar problem!"*  The villagers murmured among themselves as they formed a circle around the mayor.
Lila squeezed her way to the front, her heart pounding with curiosity.

*"Yesterday,"* the mayor began, *"a traveling merchant came to our village with three magnificent treasures: a golden harp that plays itself, a silver mirror that shows the future, and a velvet bag that never runs out of coins.
He offered to sell them to me for a great sum, but I only had enough gold for one.
So, I asked him which was the most valuable.
And do you know what he said?"*  The villagers leaned in, waiting.
*"He said, ‘The most valuable is the one you need most.’ But how am I to know which that is?"* The mayor threw up his hands.
*"I thought the harp would bring joy, the mirror would bring wisdom, and the bag would bring wealth.
But now I’m not so sure!"*  The villagers began to argue among themselves.
Some said the harp was best, others the mirror, and a few insisted the bag of coins was the wisest choice.
Lila’s grandmother listened quietly, her fingers tapping thoughtfully against her chin.
Then, just as the arguing grew louder, a small voice piped up.
*"May I ask the merchant a question?"*  The crowd turned to see Lila standing tall, her chin lifted with determination.
The mayor blinked in surprise. *"You?
But you’re just a child!"*  *"Even children can ask wise questions,"* Lila said, remembering her grandmother’s words.
*"And sometimes, the right question is the answer."*  The mayor hesitated, then shrugged. *"Very well.
Ask your question."*  Lila turned to the merchant, who had been watching the commotion with amusement.
*"Sir,"* she said, *"if you had to choose one of these treasures to keep for yourself, which would it be?"*  The merchant’s eyes gleamed.
*"Ah, a clever question indeed!
I would keep the silver mirror, for it shows not just the future, but the truth of the present.
With it, I would always know the right path to take."*  The villagers fell silent, considering his words.
Then, one by one, they began to nod. *"He’s right,"* said the baker.
*"Wealth and joy are fleeting, but wisdom lasts a lifetime."*  *"The mirror it is!"* declared the mayor, clapping his hands.
*"Thank you, young Lila, for your cleverness!"*  The villagers cheered, and Lila beamed with pride.
But as the crowd dispersed, she noticed her grandmother watching her with a knowing smile.
*"You see?"* Grandmother said, placing a gentle hand on Lila’s shoulder.
*"Wisdom isn’t just about knowing the answers—it’s about asking the right questions.
And you, my dear, have a gift for it."*  Lila grinned. *"Does that mean I’m wise too?"*  Grandmother laughed.
*"Wiser than you know. Now, come—let’s enjoy the feast!

I hear there are honey cakes with our names on them."*  And so, under a sky filled with laughter and the sweet music of the golden harp (which the mayor had bought as a second treasure, just for fun), Lila danced and feasted, knowing that the greatest treasure of all was the wisdom she carried in her heart.
